qas.question: Who lived at Buckingham Palace during WWI?

answers.text: King George V and Queen Mary

context: During <a5_0>World War I<a5_0/>, the palace, then the home of <a0_0><b10_0>King George V and Queen Mary<b10_0/><a0_0/>, escaped unscathed. Its more valuable contents were evacuated to <a1_0><a6_0><b11_0>Windsor<b11_0/><a6_0/><a1_0/> but the royal family remained in situ. The King imposed rationing at the palace, much to the dismay of his guests and household. To the King's later regret, <a4_0><a8_0><b14_0>David Lloyd George<b14_0/><a8_0/><a4_0/> persuaded him to go further by ostentatiously locking the wine cellars and refraining from <a2_0><a7_0><b12_0>alcohol<b12_0/><a7_0/><a2_0/>, to set a good example to the supposedly inebriated working class. The workers continued to imbibe and the King was left unhappy at his enforced abstinence. In <a3_0><b13_0>1938<b13_0/><a3_0/>, the north-west pavilion, designed by Nash as a conservatory, was converted into a <a9_0>swimming pool<a9_0/>.
